content.text: Use an expression for work done, in terms of force, to show that the SI base units of energy are \(\mathrm{kgm}^2 \mathrm{s}^{-2}\)
The energy \(E\) stored in an electrical component is given by
where \(Q\) is charge and \(C\) is a constant
Use this equation and the information in **(a)** to determine the SI base units of \(C\)
Measurements of a constant current in a wire are taken using an analogue ammeter
For these measurements, describe one possible cause of:
1. a random error
2. a systematic error
State Newton's second law of motion
On Fig. 2.1, draw an arrow from point X to show the direction of the acceleration of the parcel when it is at that point
Determine the height \(h\) of the parcel above the ground when it is released
Calculate the horizontal distance \(d\) between points P and Q

A delivery company suggests using a remote-controlled aircraft to drop a parcel into the garden of a customer. When the aircraft is vertically above point P on the ground, it releases the parcel with a velocity that is horizontal and of magnitude \(5.4 \text{ m s}^{-1}\). The path of the parcel is shown in Fig. 2.1
The parcel takes a time of 0.81 s after its release to reach point Q on the horizontal ground. Assume air resistance is negligible
On Fig. 2.2, draw arrows to show the directions of the forces acting on the parcel as it falls vertically downwards. Label each arrow with the name of the force
By considering the forces acting on the parcel, state and explain the variation, if any, of the acceleration of the parcel as it moves downwards before it reaches constant (terminal) speed
Describe the energy conversion that occurs when the parcel is falling through the air at constant (terminal) speed
Another parcel is accidentally released from rest by a different aircraft when it is hovering at a great height above the ground. Air resistance is now significant
State two conditions for an object to be in equilibrium
Calculate:
1. the tension \(T\) in the wire
2. the force \(F\) exerted by the string on the sphere
The wire has a circular cross-section of diameter \(0.50 \text{mm}\). Determine the stress \(\sigma\) in the wire

A sphere of weight \(2.4 \text{N}\) is suspended by a wire from a fixed point P. A horizontal string is used to hold the sphere in equilibrium with the wire at an angle of \(53^{\circ}\) to the horizontal, as shown in Fig. 3.1
Show that the vertical distance \(h\) between A and B is \(15\mathrm{cm}\)
Calculate the change in gravitational potential energy of the sphere as it moves from A to B
change in gravitational potential energy = ............................................... J
Use your answer in **(c)**(ii) to determine the speed of the sphere at B
Show your working
The string is disconnected from the sphere in **(b)**. The sphere then swings from its initial rest position A, as illustrated in Fig. 3.2
The sphere reaches maximum speed when it is at the bottom of the swing at position B. The distance between P and the centre of the sphere is \(75\mathrm{cm}\)
Air resistance is negligible and energy losses at P are negligible
By reference to the direction of propagation of energy, state what is meant by a longitudinal wave
State the principle of superposition
Calculate the wavelength, in nm, of the light
The intensity of the light passing through each slit was initially the same. The intensity of the light through one of the slits is now reduced
Compare the appearance of the fringes before and after the change of intensity
The wavelength of light from a laser is determined using the apparatus shown in Fig. 4.1
The light from the laser is incident normally on the plane of the double slit
The separation of the two slits is \(3.7 \times 10^{-4} \text{m}\). The screen is parallel to the plane of the double slit. The distance between the screen and the double slit is \(2.3 \text{m}\)
A pattern of bright fringes and dark fringes is seen on the screen. The separation of adjacent bright fringes on the screen is \(4.3 \times 10^{-3} \text{m}\)
Show that the wire has a cross-sectional area of \(4.5 \times 10^{- 7} \text{m}^2\)
The potential difference across the total length of wire is \(1.8 \text{V}\)
Calculate the current in the wire
current =   .........  A
The number density of the free electrons in the wire is \(6.1 \times 10^{28} \text{m}^{- 3}\)
Calculate the average drift speed of the free electrons in the wire
average drift speed =   .........  \(\text{ms}^{-1}\)

Metal wire is used to connect a power supply to a lamp. The wire has a total resistance of \(3.4 \Omega\) and the metal has a resistivity of \(2.6 \times 10^{- 8} \Omega \text{m}\). The total length of the wire is \(59 \text{m}\)
State and explain qualitatively how the average drift speed of the free electrons in the thinner part compares with that in the rest of the wire
State and explain whether the power dissipated in the thinner part is the same, less or more than the power dissipated in an equal length of the rest of the wire
A different wire carries a current. This wire has a part that is thinner than the rest of the wire, as shown in Fig. 5.1
Sketch a diagram showing how two of these three resistors may be connected together to give a combined resistance of \(60\Omega\) between the terminals shown
Ensure you label the values of the resistances in your diagram

A potential divider circuit is produced by connecting the three resistors to a battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(12\mathrm{V}\) and negligible internal resistance. The potential divider circuit provides an output potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\) of \(8.0\mathrm{V}\)
Fig. 5.2 shows the circuit diagram
On Fig. 5.2, label the resistances of all three resistors and the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\)
Three resistors have resistances of \(180\Omega , 90\Omega\) and \(30\Omega .\)
Determine the magnitude of the electric field strength between the plates
electric field strength =   .........  \(NC^{-1}\)
State the direction of the electric field
Two horizontal metal plates are separated by a distance of \(2.0 \text{cm}\) in a vacuum, as shown in Fig. 6.1
The top plate has an electric potential of \(+180 \text{V}\) and the bottom plate has an electric potential of \(-120 \text{V}\)
Determine the number of protons, neutrons and electrons in the particle (ion) X
number of protons =
number of neutrons =
number of electrons =
The particle (ion) X is in the electric field in **(a)** at a point midway between the plates
Determine the magnitude of the electric force acting on X

The nucleus of uranium-238 ( \(^{238}_{92}\mathrm{U})\) decays in stages, by emitting \(\alpha\) -particles and \(\beta^{- }\) particles, to form a nucleus of thorium-230 ( \(^{230}_{90}\mathrm{Th})\)
Calculate the total number of \(\alpha\) -particles and the total number of \(\beta^{- }\) particles that are emitted during the decay of uranium-238 to thorium-230
number of \(\alpha\)-particles =
number of \(\beta^{- }\) particles =

An uncharged atom of uranium-238 ( \(^{238}_{92}\mathrm {U})\) has a change made to its number of orbital electrons. This causes the atom to change into a new particle (ion) X that has an overall charge of \(+2e,\) where e is the elementary charge
